other_uses_comment: in comparative constructions, "Aún with an accent must be distinguished from aun ‘even’, although its meaning sometimes overlaps with aun"

comment: In parts of Latin America siempre ‘always’ can, like the French toujours, mean ‘still’. "Seguir is more often used before adjectives and participles, i.e. one says sigue enfermo ‘he’s still ill/sick’ rather than continúa enfermo". The construction seguir + Vndo is disfavored with stative verbs
te(?)-be(cnt) is a reinforced continutative, with negation is just neg-cnt-; prohibited with non-homogeneous predicates
other_uses_comment: be- prefix (without te-) has a progressive meaning (with non-finite forms), avertive meaning (with a past auxiliary 'be')
meaning_with_negation_comment: no longer, ne-be- (without an intenisifier), cf. a synonymous particle nebe. ne-be- also has discourse functions of counter-expectation.

comment: vis 'constantly' is often added as an intensifier
